subject: Art
title: Color Context Effects
description: How the same color looks completely different depending on context.

hook.text: Place a gray square on a white background â€” it looks dark. Place the same gray on a black background â€” it looks light. Same gray. Different perception. Context rewrites reality.

buildup.text: Context effects include: simultaneous contrast (surrounding colors shift perception), size of area (small areas of color appear more saturated), and adjacency (neighboring colors blend at edges).

discovery.text: Josef Albers proved that we almost never see color as it physically is. Every color is modified by its surroundings. This means you can make any color 'work' by controlling what surrounds it.

twist.text: This is why selecting colors on a white palette misleads you. A color looks completely different on your palette than on your canvas surrounded by other colors. Always judge in context.

climax.text: Experiment: paint the same gray circle on six different colored backgrounds. Watch it appear to change hue, value, and saturation â€” even though every gray is identical.

punchline.text: Color is a chameleon. It changes with every neighbor. Master context and you master color.

quiz.question: Why should you judge colors on the canvas rather than the palette?
options: Colors look different when surrounded by other colors on the canvas
